questions.neutral: You look like you dodged something - true?

hobby.message: Freestyle FPV... your kind of silence, right?
Any luck fixing the old typewriter?

wrong_hobby_answer: That's not me. In free time, I take analog photographs. They capture the truth in a way that digital can't.
neutral_answer: Maybe I got lucky, hard to say right now.
Spent some time walking with my camera. Nothing unusual.
Analog photography. Sometimes helps clear my head.
These days you take what moments you can get.
Dodged enough for one day.
Been out shooting street photos with my old camera.
Analog film, not easy to come by lately.
Score amnesty made folks act different, even in public.
Couldn’t let that go undocumented.
Could be dodging, could be chasing.
I shoot street photos on 35mm film. Real, not digital.
Today, the whole city felt off—people letting their guard down.
Used the amnesty to capture some honest moments, finally.
Haven’t seen that in years.
Film’s limited, but sometimes the risk is worth it.
Yeah, dodged a data sweep or two. Perks of shooting analog.
I use smuggled 35mm film—captures things surveillance misses.
The amnesty changed the streets. People showed faces for once.
Saw two BCI ghosts in broad daylight. They didn’t shy away.
Caught a council clerk buying bread, no security detail.
Risked burning two rolls for those shots.
Feels like the old city, even if just for a few hours.
You’re right—I’ve been dodging more than just BCI today.
Photography’s my rebellion. Analog film only—digital’s never honest here.
Had to smuggle the last batch in from outside Stenograd.
When the score amnesty hit, something changed. People dropped the act.
Ghosts let me take portraits. No one shielded their face.
Used up both rolls—worth every frame. Even caught protest slogans graffitiing in daylight.
Those raw shots might vanish soon, but I won’t.
Mom used to delete film for the BCI. Guess I’m making up for it.
hobby_answer: Yeah, still somehow breathing.
Film’s expensive, but luck was on my side this week.
Rolled out during the amnesty window. Didn’t get hassled.
People pretended they didn’t see me.
That’s about all there is to it.
Still clicking. Just less obvious about it.
The two-week reset? Made it easier to walk around.
People relaxed a bit. Good shots, but nothing lasts.
I stayed in busy spots. No one asks questions there.
Developing film’s risky, but I’ve got ways.
Bar 101’s close enough if trouble shows up.
Analog’s alive. I was out early during the amnesty.
People’s guard dropped for the first time in ages.
Got both rolls used before noon. Caught more faces than usual.
Even some old ghosts wanted portraits.
Feels like reporting—just slower and quieter.
Film’s tricky to get, chemicals worse.
If the reset ends, I won’t get a chance like that again.
Analog survived and thrived this week, actually.
The amnesty meant everyone stepped out of their digital shells.
Took street portraits I couldn’t get in years.
A few returned ‘ghosts’ let me shoot them, direct. They knew me from before.
You could feel real life under the surface.
It was like the system blinked and we remembered ourselves.
I even smuggled some shots into the newsroom archive.
Makes you wonder who’s really watching, when the tech fails.
Analog’s my stubborn protest. Recorded a city waking up from surveillance.
After Halden’s death, the system glitched. BCI reset was a lifeline—even for film.
During amnesty, caught real moments: ghosts back, people open, no nervous glances.
Got a shot of a ghost hugging his daughter on Lenin Avenue. No way before this.
Developed film in the old supply closet—safe, even joked with a restored editor.
Every frame felt urgent, like we were all holding our breath together.
If the Directorate regains control, this goes underground again.
But I saw hope. People wanted to be seen—really seen.
Kept a set of prints safe. Maybe for when it matters most.
